Voice control is supported, meaning you won‚Äôt always have to adjust settings or manage the lights manually via the dedicated app. It plays nicely with Alexa and Google Assistant, so you can say something like ‚ÄúHey Alexa, turn the lights on‚Äù, or ‚ÄúHey Alexa, increase the brightness‚Äù, and your command will be answered in seconds. The Hue Bridge brings even more convenience by letting you add motion sensors, set routines, create timers, and more. There‚Äôs a lot more to like about this smart lighting strip. It does more than adding lights to your setup; it creates a vibe. The current deal lets you pick the 65-inch version for $130, after an impressive 56% discount. item.title: Xbox Clears Out Elite Series 2 Core Gaming Controllers at Their Lowest Price to Compete With PlayStation and Switch
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôve already bought an Xbox for the holidays, there are a couple of small issues you thankfully still have time to address. One, it comes with one controller, so if you‚Äôre in a multi-player home, that‚Äôs going to be an issue. Two, that default controller is good ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not great.

The Xbox Elite Series 2 wireless controller that‚Äôs on sale for 33% off right now at Amazon? Indisputably great, so you can get that second controller and a pro gaming experience at the same time by taking this $135 deal. The Elite 2 works with Xbox One, Series S, and Series X, and also works for PC gaming.

Premium Feel

The upgrade from the default Xbox controller to the Elite 2 is obvious from the second you take it out of the box. It‚Äôs slightly thicker and has a heavier feel, but just enough heft that it feels sturdy and well-built. The rubberized grips give you a feeling of secure control, and overall it‚Äôs ergonomically outstanding, designed for long sessions.

The construction already sets the Elite 2 apart from the default Xbox controller and third-party versions, but where it really takes off into the stratosphere is when you get to customize it. The tension on the thumbsticks can be finely adjusted, and the triggers are shorter and faster for an edge in shooters and battle royals. The thumbsticks, d-pads and paddles are all swappable, so it‚Äôs as close to custom-designing a controller for yourself as you can find.

Take the customization further by using the Xbox Accessories app on the console or on a PC to remap buttons, set up multiple profiles and custom stick curves, and even assign macros. The profiles can be stored on the Elite 2 itself so you can change them on the fly, which means you can set up different ones for different games.

Endurance Level Battery

Where the default Xbox controller is powered by AA batteries and also somewhat notorious for chewing through them at a rapid rate, the Elite 2 is rechargeable. You get up to 40 hours of gameplay on a single charge, and the USB-C charging dock is included. You can game all day and rest the Elite 2 on its dock by night to ensure you‚Äôll have a full charge every time you fire up the console or PC.

The upgrades from the default controller to the Elite 2 are staggering, so much so that it‚Äôll entirely reshape how you play. Even if you‚Äôre not in need of a second controller, upgrading to the Elite 2 and keeping the default controller on hand as a backup is a smart move. Now‚Äôs the time to make the switch ‚Äî Amazon‚Äôs 33% off deal brings the Xbox Elite Series 2 wireless controller with its charger and swappable components down to a very reasonable $135.

item.title: What Did You Think Of The Game Awards 2025
item.content:encoded:
Another Game Awards showcase has come and gone. What did you think? Did you stay up and watch or just skim the highlights on social media? Did the right games win in the right categories? Did any of the ‚Äúworld premier‚Äù trailer reveals make you feel like Geoff Keighley‚Äôs event earned its nearly four-hour runtime? Consider this an open thread to chat, joke, and share your thoughts.

I‚Äôll start. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 won more awards than any game in TGA history. Personally, while I love the game and think it warrants the hype, that seems a bit overblown. Will it stand the test of time like formative winners including The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Elden Ring, and Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3? I suspect not, but maybe not reinventing the wheel shouldn‚Äôt be held against it. It‚Äôs the game of the moment and this is the awards show for 2025.

At the very least, it shouldn‚Äôt have won best indie game. I blame the TGA jury for that one. If one of the goals of the show is to highlight as many of the year‚Äôs best games as possible, maybe one game shouldn‚Äôt be able to win ‚Äúbest game‚Äù across multiple categories. If you picked Clair Obscur for GOTY, it can‚Äôt also win ‚Äúbest RPG‚Äù or ‚Äúbest debut indie game.‚Äù It would prevent sweeps like this, which, even if deserved, end up being kind of boring and leave so many other amazing games underrepresented on the big stage.

Give it up in the chat for Miss Piggy and Rowlf the Dog! üëèüëè@TheMuppets never let us down! #TheGameAwards pic.twitter.com/XY6VxHLiYa

‚Äî The Game Awards (@thegameawards) December 12, 2025

And what about the reveals? Keighley tried to pull another Okami 2-style rabbit out of his hat with Mega Man Dual Overdrive (aka Mega Man 12). As someone who grew up on games in the NES-era, Mega Man 3 gave me a daily ass-kicking for years, it sort of worked. That game isn‚Äôt coming until 2027 though, and didn‚Äôt look nearly as solid or revelatory in the gameplay and art than I‚Äôd expect for the Blue Bomber‚Äôs prodigal return. Insiders promise Capcom is cooking but they have their work cut out for them.

The show also seemed light on some of those known quantities that bring a special X factor to a showcase like this. No Nintendo wasn‚Äôt surprising. Sony showed showed more Saros but that doesn‚Äôt quite pop has much as more Wolverine or a new God of War would have. Microsoft, Square Enix, Ubisoft, and the rest of the big publishers were absent too. The big show stoppers, a new Divinity RPG from Larian Studios and a new Star Wars: The Old Republic spin-off from ex-BioWare director Casey Hudson, are games I can‚Äôt wait to play but whose reveals were muted a bit by brief cinematic teasers that shared a vibe but not a story.

In many ways, this might have been the smoothest and most slickly produced Game Awards yet. It also, for some reason, felt like one of the least memorable. Will see if that gut assessment holds up a couple years from now. What did you think?

item.title: Bradley The Badger Was The True Star Of The Game Awards
item.content:encoded:
While the main show of The Game Awards featured some big reveals and cinematic extravaganzas, it was during the pre-show that the real star appeared. An action-platform game called Bradley the Badger, that looks to be four-dimensional folding layers of meta about gaming, with multiple jovial jabs taken at names like The Last Of Us, Cyberpunk 2077 and Dark Souls.

Beginning with the conceit that we‚Äôre already big, nostalgic fans of Bradley, a cheerfully-colored mascot platforming character who‚Äôd be right at home in the PS2 era, Bradley the Badger‚Äòs trailer sees the titular character enthusiastically setting out on his latest adventure, to discover his house is now inside some sort of grimdark Soulslike. Walls are made of petrified hands, some holding blue-glowing lanterns, and then a title card drops in reading ‚ÄúBadgerborne.‚Äù But as Bradley to platform around in this unpleasant reality, he discovers that it‚Äôs very much not finished. Art assets are marked as ‚ÄúWAITING FOR REVIEW,‚Äù while sticky notes appear all over demanding fixes.

This, Bradley discovers, means he can start manipulating these unfinished textures and placeholder blocks, such that he can drag and reshape his own platforms, or reprogram the properties of items. And there, there you‚Äôve got a brilliant idea for a game.

Except it keeps adding. Once Bradley‚Äôs in a Cyberpunk 2077 reality, he‚Äôs able to transform himself into untextured items in the world, becoming a trash bin that can roll up walls, or in a The Last Of Us spoof turn into both a pick-up truck and a size-changing apple. This all starts to look really incredible, the game not demanding players learn code (thank god), but rather just having toggles for various settings of each item, explosive or inert, big or small, magnetic or not. And just as you‚Äôre getting to grips with what this is all about, Bradley reaches the end of what‚Äôs been coded in the game. And wakes up. As a real person, FMV, with filthy human feet and hands, and a dirty, ill-fitting badger hat on his head. He‚Äôs in the development studios of Dreamwoods Games, the walls covered in Bradley posters and notes, and at that point I have no idea what this is.

The game‚Äôs Steam page makes things a bit clearer. This is, at heart, an action-platformer, but one where you have ‚Äúgame developer powers.‚Äù But on top of that, it‚Äôs a game about a beloved franchise becoming self-aware, realizing his fictional reality, and fighting against it to try to restore his normality. And then, yes, the story will include live-actions sections too. Which is glorious.

Evan Peters, the X-Men movies‚Äô Peter Maximoff, plays the real-world version and voice of Bradley, in the first game from Day 4 Night Studios, the first game from team of former AAA devs who have variously worked on games like GTA: San Andreas, Mario + Rabbids, and Dead Alliance. One of the co-creators, Christian Cantamessa, calls Bradley the Badger ‚Äúpart love letter to video games and part satire of them.‚Äù

The game is set for a Steam release in 2026, but will clearly be looking for console releases after its TGA appearance.
